title: Keith Tam
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : Keith Chi-hang Tam**

Keith Tam was born and raised in Hong Kong and has lived in the UK and Canada. He is a communication designer who specializes in typography. He is a lecturer of Visual Communication at the School of Design, The [Hong Kong Polytechnic University](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Hong%20Kong%20Polytechnic%20University), with a focus on typographic and publication design. Keith's design and research interests include book and editorial design, information design, typeface design, [calligraphy](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/calligraphy) and lettering, visual identities and designing for multiple languages. He is the designer behind [Arrival](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Arrival), a legible and humane sanserif typeface designed for directional signing, currently used by the campus wayfinding system of the [University of Reading](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/University%20of%20Reading), UK. He co-founded [Type Initiative](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Type%20Initiative) with Greek type designer [Michail Semoglou](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Michail%20Semoglou) in 2005, and their typefaces are on sale at the type co-op [Village](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Village). Keith holds a B Des in Communication Design from the [Emily Carr Institute](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Emily%20Carr%20Institute) in [Vancouver](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Vancouver), [Canada](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Canada) and an MA in Typeface Design from the Department of Typography & Graphic Communication at the University of Reading, UK.

He was also noticeably absent from [Typecon](http://web.archive.org/web/20131101072832/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Typecon) 2005 which made many people angry, or at least sad.
